content.question: The motion of an object moving along a straight line is described by the acceleration versus time graph in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. A student claims that the motion of the object can also be represented by the velocity versus time graph in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Which of the following correctly states whether or not the student’s claim is true and explains why?

choices.label: No, because the object’s speed is increasing, the acceleration should be positive.
No, because the object’s speed is increasing, the acceleration should be increasing in magnitude.
Yes, because the area under the curve of the acceleration versus time graph could represent a negative velocity that would be increasing in magnitude.
Yes, because the slope of the graph of acceleration versus time is constant, so the velocity of the object approaches a constant value.

content.answer: Yes, because the area under the curve of the acceleration versus time graph could represent a negative velocity that would be increasing in magnitude.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
